name: 3,3,3-trifluoro-2-hydroxy-2-(trifluoromethyl)propionic acid
Reason: 3,3,3-trifluoro-2-hydroxy-2-(trifluoromethyl)propionic acid has a melting point that we will analyze by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is propionic acid, which has a melting point of -10.5 °C. The trifluoromethyl group introduces a significant dipole due to the electronegativity of fluorine, raising the melting point by approximately +20 °C. The three fluorine atoms increase the molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, contributing about +20 °C each. The hydroxyl group introduces hydrogen bonding potential, which might lower the melting point by approximately -5 °C. The carbonyl group introduces a polar carbonyl interaction, raising the melting point by approximately +30 °C. The trifluoromethyl group also introduces a rigid structure, which might participate in dipole interactions and raise the melting point by approximately +10 °C.
